newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee off lows by close on panic buying.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee off lows by close on panic buying.

text.p: Coffee futures pulled back from the lows by panic price-fixing buying ahead of Friday's first November tender day but still ended down on earlier speculative selling.
"Apart from it going berserk, we had a lot of panicky fixing against carrying-in this afternoon," said a trader.

"We got until tomorrow to fix (prices)," she said. Friday is the first notice/tender day for spot month November contract. By the close, January stood $10 down at $1,390 a tonne after hitting a low of $1,365. But it stopped short of challenging an immediate support at $1,360.
The spot November led the losers as some players rolled over their November positions into January before the spot expiry.
This helped narrow the hefty November premium to January to $95 by the close from Tuesday's $122.
Volume on the exchange reached 3,703 lots.
Traders said the active Nov/Jan switch saw some trades at $110 after ranging between $86 and $128. The Jan/March spread saw deals at $55 and $65.
Traders said the Nov/Jan spread, until now backed by tight availability of nearby supplies, could come under pressure from next week as more fresh coffee is graded and tendered.
Origins are keen to unload coffee to be in time for the November delivery in view of the relatively large November premium.
In other news, traders kept a close eye on the crisis in Zaire following escalated fighting in the eastern part of the country where most of its crop is grown.
With the main Zairean crop is not due until December, traders said there was no cause for panic yet. But they said supplies could be threatened if chaos persisted.
